definition: A preposition (पूर्वसर्ग) in Sanskrit is a word that connects a noun or pronoun to other words in a sentence, usually indicating relationships such as location, direction, time, manner, etc.

categories.description: Prepositions of location indicate where something is located or the position of something.

in: गृहे अस्ति (He is in the house)
on: मेजे पुस्तकं अस्ति (The book is on the table)
under: पुस्तकं मेज के अधः अस्ति (The book is under the table)
near: रामे समीपे पुस्तकं अस्ति (The book is near Rama)
inside: गृहस्य अन्तरे पुस्तकं अस्ति (The book is inside the house)
outside: गृहस्य बाह्ये पुस्तकं अस्ति (The book is outside the house)

categories.description: Prepositions of direction indicate the movement or direction towards something.

into: गृहं प्रति गच्छ (Go into the house)
out of: गृहात् बाह्यं गच्छ (Go out of the house)

categories.description: Prepositions of time indicate when an action takes place or the duration of an action.
Prepositions of manner indicate how or in what way something is done.

with: पत्नीया साथ पठति (She reads with the wife)
like: गंगा समान जलं अस्ति (The Ganga has water like the ocean)

categories.description: Prepositions of cause or reason indicate why something happens or the cause of an action.

for: रामाय पुस्तकं दत्तं (The book was given for Rama)
because of: दुःखं कारणं अस्ति (It is because of sorrow)

categories.description: Prepositions of accompaniment describe what or whom something is done with.

types_of_prepositions.description: These are basic prepositions that typically describe relationships such as location, direction, time, etc.
These are formed by combining two simple prepositions or a preposition with a noun.
These prepositions do not follow a specific form but are used to show general relationships.
